path_1.title: Les Misérables in Concert - The 25th Anniversary (2010)
path_1.feeling: Lavish stage singing isn’t my thing, so the emotion didn’t land.

path_1.title: Matrix, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Slick, heady sci‑fi about agency hits my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)
path_1.feeling: The school politics and teen rebellion arc felt middling to me.

path_1.title: Safety Not Guaranteed (2012)
path_1.feeling: Quirky time‑travel premise with a sincere heart—fun and clever.

path_1.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_1.feeling: Moody, methodical crime tale with a strong father‑son core.

path_1.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_1.feeling: Razor‑sharp, infuriating exposé that scratches my investigative itch.

path_1.title: Prisoners (2013)
path_1.feeling: Gripping moral maze that kept me tense and thinking.

path_1.title: They/Them (2022)
path_1.feeling: The slasher and social commentary felt clumsy rather than thrilling.

path_1.title: Super 8 (2011)
path_1.feeling: Nostalgic creature‑feature charm with solid suspense.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Fate vs. free will romance that I enjoy despite the neatness.

path_1.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous world‑building and contemplative sci‑fi I can sink into.

path_1.title: No Escape (2015)
path_1.feeling: Tense setup, but it plays like a serviceable run‑and‑gun.

path_1.title: True Grit (2010)
path_1.feeling: Classic, sturdy western with grit and heart.

path_1.title: Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008)
path_1.feeling: Loud, cartoonish galactic antics leave me cold.

path_1.title: Da Vinci Code, The (2006)
path_1.feeling: Pulp puzzle‑box plotting that goes down easy enough.

path_1.title: Hustlers (2019)
path_1.feeling: Slick, savvy caper with a satisfying Wall Street sting.

path_1.title: Forgetting Sarah Marshall (2008)
path_1.feeling: Goofy breakup balm with just enough heart to work.

path_1.title: Amityville Horror, The (2005)
path_1.feeling: Familiar haunted‑house beats, few real chills.

path_1.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_1.feeling: Razor‑edged thriller with media mind games I relish.

path_1.title: Drive (2011)
path_1.feeling: Cool and tense, though the affect can feel a bit distant.

path_1.title: Shirley (2020)
path_1.feeling: Writerly mood and menace intrigued me but kept me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Truman Show, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: Smart, crowd‑pleasing high‑concept about control and authenticity.

path_1.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
path_1.feeling: A dour road movie chapter that drags between highlights.

path_1.title: The Magnificent Seven (2016)
path_1.feeling: Decent shootouts, light on lasting impression.

path_1.title: The Gray Man (2022)
path_1.feeling: Glossy globe‑trotting with thin characters didn’t hook me.

path_1.title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)
path_1.feeling: Pulpy subterranean rescue that’s more noise than wonder.

path_1.title: Chappie (2015)
path_1.feeling: Earnest robo‑coming‑of‑age that’s uneven but watchable.

path_2.title: Les Misérables in Concert - The 25th Anniversary
path_2.feeling: Impressive vocals, but the staged pageantry leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Matrix, The
path_2.feeling: Iconic, idea-driven action that nails momentum and mind-bend.

path_2.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
path_2.feeling: Darker stakes help, but the YA wizard politicking still feels fluffy to me.

path_2.title: Safety Not Guaranteed
path_2.feeling: Low-key and charming with just enough sci-fi to keep me engaged.

path_2.title: Road to Perdition
path_2.feeling: Somber, elegant crime tale where the father–son bond gives the violence weight.

path_2.title: Inside Job
path_2.feeling: A meticulous, infuriating expose that scratches my institutional-rot itch.

path_2.title: Prisoners
path_2.feeling: A grim, absorbing moral maze that sinks its hooks in.

path_2.title: They/Them
path_2.feeling: Strong premise, but the slasher beats feel blunt and generic.

path_2.title: Super 8
path_2.feeling: Nostalgic monster vibes land, but sentiment and spectacle dilute the mystery.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The
path_2.feeling: Fate-vs-free-will chase with a romantic hook that mostly works.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049
path_2.feeling: Moody and gorgeous, but the pace and self-seriousness keep me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: No Escape

path_2.title: True Grit

path_2.title: Star Wars: The Clone Wars
path_2.feeling: Prequel-era bombast and kiddie animation leave me unmoved.

path_2.title: Da Vinci Code, The
path_2.feeling: Page-turner plotting, but the conspiracy lore feels silly and weightless.

path_2.title: Hustlers
path_2.feeling: A sharp, entertaining swindle with a timely Wall Street sting, if a bit glossy.

path_2.title: Forgetting Sarah Marshall
path_2.feeling: Goofy but sweet breakup balm that lands enough laughs.

path_2.title: Amityville Horror, The

path_2.title: Gone Girl

path_2.title: Drive

path_2.title: Shirley
path_2.feeling: A prickly, claustrophobic study that intrigues more than it grips.

path_2.title: Truman Show, The
path_2.feeling: Prescient media-surveillance fable that still lands emotionally.

path_2.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1
path_2.feeling: Darker and more grounded, but the split story plays like a long prologue.

path_2.title: The Gray Man
path_2.feeling: Glossy, weightless espionage—momentum without much intrigue.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Media-circus mind games and toxic dynamics make for a cold, gripping thriller I can sink into

path_5.title: Drive (2011)
path_5.feeling: Cool-burn neo-noir where mood, menace, and moral gray line up for me

path_5.title: Shirley (2020)
path_5.feeling: Prickly, insinuating psych drama with creative-process dread that keeps me uneasily engaged

path_5.title: Truman Show, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Clever, humane satire of surveillance and manufactured reality that lands both ideas and feeling

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
path_5.feeling: On-the-run wizarding odyssey with dour stakes, yet the franchise vibe still doesn't fully grab me

path_5.title: The Magnificent Seven (2016)
path_5.feeling: Glossy ensemble western delivers serviceable shoot-'em-up beats without much lingering bite

path_5.title: The Gray Man (2022)
path_5.feeling: Slick globe-trotting spy mayhem that entertains in the moment but feels canned

path_5.title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)
path_5.feeling: Underground rescue adventure plays like bargain-bin sci-fi—watchable but generic

path_5.title: Chappie (2015)
path_5.feeling: AI-coming-of-age conceit intrigues, though the tonal swings keep me at arm's length

path_5.title: Les Misérables in Concert - The 25th Anniversary (2010)
path_5.feeling: Impressive vocals and pageantry, but concert staging and musical bombast just aren’t my lane.

path_5.title: Matrix, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Sleek, heady techno‑noir that hits my conspiracy/ideas sweet spot.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)
path_5.feeling: Darker school‑year stakes land, though the YA wizarding beats keep me a step removed.

path_5.title: Safety Not Guaranteed (2012)
path_5.feeling: Quirky time‑travel premise plus newsroom digging—sweet without tipping into twee for me.

path_5.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_5.feeling: Somber, morally gray crime tale with father‑son undercurrents—right in my wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_5.feeling: Scathing, lucid systemic critique—the investigative bite I respond to.

path_5.title: Prisoners (2013)
path_5.feeling: Grim, tense investigation and moral compromise—my kind of thriller.

path_5.title: They/Them (2022)
path_5.feeling: Timely premise, but the slasher‑camp execution feels blunt and undercuts the impact.

path_5.title: Super 8 (2011)
path_5.feeling: Nostalgic creature‑feature thrills work, even if the sentimental wrap keeps me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Fate‑vs‑free‑will chase with a romantic core that goes down easy and scratches my sci‑fi itch.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Gorgeous, moody future‑noir with ideas—I dig the investigation even if it runs a bit cold.

path_5.title: No Escape (2015)
path_5.feeling: Relentless set‑piece suspense, but it plays exploitative and thin on nuance for my taste.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Classically sturdy western with grit and heart that sticks.

path_5.title: Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008)
path_5.feeling: Loud, cartoony franchise filler—this corner of the galaxy just isn’t for me.

path_5.title: Da Vinci Code, The (2006)
path_5.feeling: Pulp puzzle‑box conspiracy that entertains even as the theology theatrics feel hokey.

path_5.title: Hustlers (2019)
path_5.feeling: Sharp, character‑driven caper with socio‑economic bite—I’m in.

path_5.title: Forgetting Sarah Marshall (2008)
path_5.feeling: Broad breakup laughs with enough heart to work, even if the goofiness isn’t fully my lane.

path_5.title: Amityville Horror, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Polished haunted‑house beats deliver some mood, but it’s familiar and thin.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Surgical, queasy domestic mystery with media rot—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Drive (2011)
path_5.feeling: Cool‑blooded neo‑noir with aching undercurrents and bursts of violence—my thing.

path_5.title: Shirley (2020)
path_5.feeling: Moody literary psych‑drama whose creeping unease and power games hook me.

path_5.title: Truman Show, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Clever, prescient media satire with real pathos—hits my sweet spot.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
path_5.feeling: On‑the‑run wizarding stakes keep me engaged, though the fantasy trappings limit my investment.

path_5.title: The Magnificent Seven (2016)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, crowd‑pleasing western action—entertaining, light on grit.

path_5.title: The Gray Man (2022)
path_5.feeling: Slick globe‑trotting mayhem that goes down easy but feels weightless.

path_5.title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)
path_5.feeling: Serviceable subterranean adventure that’s more pulp than awe for me.

path_5.title: Chappie (2015)
path_5.feeling: Philosophical robo‑fable with rough edges—ideas intrigue even if the tone wobbles.

path_5.title: Les Misérables in Concert - The 25th Anniversary (2010)
path_5.feeling: Impressive vocals and pageantry, but the concert staging and sentimental sweep aren’t my lane.

path_5.title: Matrix, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Propulsive, idea-rich sci-fi action that hits my paranoid/identity itch.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)
path_5.feeling: The darker institutional pushback engages me, even if the wizard-school rhythms keep me a step removed.

path_5.title: Safety Not Guaranteed (2012)
path_5.feeling: Low-key, quirky time-travel hook with a reporter angle—sweet but grounded enough to work.

path_5.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_5.feeling: Elegiac, morally gray crime tale with tight stakes—right in my wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_5.feeling: Explosive systemic critique with investigative bite—catnip for me.

path_5.title: Prisoners (2013)
path_5.feeling: Grim, nerve-tightening moral maze that pushes my thriller buttons.

path_5.title: They/Them (2022)
path_5.feeling: Promising premise and social angle, but the slasher beats feel schematic for me.

path_5.title: Super 8 (2011)
path_5.feeling: Kid-adventure nostalgia with solid suspense—even if the sentimentality keeps me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: Fate-vs-free-will chase with romantic stakes—concept scratches the itch despite the gloss.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Immersive, moody future-noir that lets me sink into mystery and moral fog.

path_5.title: No Escape (2015)
path_5.feeling: Tense, meat-and-potatoes survival thrills that satisfy even as they ride familiar beats.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Lean, character-driven western justice that hits the sweet spot.

path_5.title: Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008)
path_5.feeling: Kid-centric franchise spin-off energy that’s simply not my lane.

path_5.title: Da Vinci Code, The (2006)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, clue-chasing conspiracy that scratches my investigation itch despite the pulp.

path_5.title: Hustlers (2019)
path_5.feeling: Sexy, sharp grift with a Wall Street target—engaging moral gray even if some gloss peeks through.

path_5.title: Forgetting Sarah Marshall (2008)
path_5.feeling: Amiable breakup-vacation hijinks—fun in spots, a bit too broad for my taste.

path_5.title: Amityville Horror, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: Familiar haunted-house chills elevated by a moody atmosphere—solid if unsurprising.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Cold, razor-sharp manipulation and media spin—squarely in my thriller wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Drive (2011)
path_5.feeling: Cool-burn neo-noir with moral rot simmering under the style—right in my lane.

path_5.title: Shirley (2020)
path_5.feeling: Prickly, claustrophobic creative-paranoia psychodrama that keeps me uneasily hooked.

path_5.title: Truman Show, The (1998)
path_5.feeling: Clever, humane surveillance fable that taps my reality-control anxieties.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
path_5.feeling: Darker, on-the-run stakes work better for me, though the franchise trappings temper my investment.

path_5.title: The Magnificent Seven (2016)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, serviceable shoot-’em-up western—entertaining without the grit I prefer.

path_5.title: The Gray Man (2022)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, weightless spy-chase thrills that go down easy and fade just as fast.

path_5.title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)
path_5.feeling: Lightweight subterranean adventure whose cartoonish beats keep me at a distance.

path_5.title: Chappie (2015)
path_5.feeling: Kid-like AI coming-of-age with grime and heart—the concept hooks me even if the tone wobbles.
